documentation.title: What is the best way to search through session laws?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I've done a lot of digging through the codified statutes, at least in my jurisdiction. I'm wondering if there is an efficient way to search through the session laws to find where the related session law is which corresponds to a codified law. Often, the session laws are titled something that may not contain a relatable key word. And they're ordered chronologically. I'm mainly interested in seeing the progression of a chaptered statute as it is changed over many years or even decades and possibly centuries. I'm sure there's an old fashioned way of doing this search and a new technologically improved way, too. I suppose I would need to know both, depending on how far back in history I wish to be looking.

The reason I am looking is because I am looking for evidence of intent for when the law was created. 

If this is a question that will only be answerable in a jurisdiction\-specific way, then I'm asking about Maine and the Federal Government.

(No, I am not in school, and no this is not my homework.)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The best place to find intent is the legislative history, and you're right, the session laws' text or even its bill numbers are not printed in the history of the statute (and are titled and chartered differently). They are much more difficult to research than statutes. In the notation after the statute, sometimes, in some states, it will list the session laws in order from the first enactment through all of its legislative changes to its current form. And then you can backtrack.

That said if you're not using a professional search site, there is nearly no way to just find them through a Google or Findlaw search. Some states may assign an archaic system to their indexing. I've seen, where it will have state abbreviation, say MA, the year, 2012, then the actual numerical filing order, then the session – e.g., MA12\-3694\-1\. However, to find the legislative session, you need to use a Boolean logic search on Lexis or West, or use your local law librarian. Also, many states legislative webpages now have them. You can use Lexis and Westlaw at the law library, for free.

If you don't have a professional search engine, you can use one at any local law library.

### BASIC RESEARCH STEPS

1. Identify the state Code section you wish to research.
2. Find which session law created the language.
3. Determine which bill created the law.
4. Trace the procedural history of the bill during its passage.

Then, at the law library, you can read the various discussions on the floor relating to intent, as well as listen to the hearings on audio for more recent enactments (past 50 years or so). This is especially useful if it was a contested bill or if it was brought about by some sort of social or political climate at the time. In some places, for instance where I live, if you call your court's law library the librarian will compile it for you if you know the statute for which you want the legislative history searched. I've done that many times and they don't mind doing it.

41.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A legal researcher is trying to find evidence of legislative intent for a specific statute in Maine. Which of the following methods would be most efficient and comprehensive for tracing the progression of the statute and uncovering its legislative history?

A) Conducting a Google search using keywords related to the statute's subject matter
B) Browsing through chronologically ordered session laws in the state archives
C) Using a professional legal research database like Lexis or Westlaw at a law library to perform Boolean logic searches
D) Relying solely on the notation after the statute in the current codified version

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A) While a Google search might provide some general information, it is not an efficient or comprehensive method for finding specific legislative history and intent.

B) Browsing chronologically ordered session laws would be extremely time-consuming and may not provide a complete picture of the statute's progression.

C) This is the correct answer. Using professional legal research databases at a law library allows for efficient Boolean logic searches, access to session laws, bill histories, and legislative discussions. This method provides the most comprehensive approach to tracing a statute's progression and uncovering legislative intent.

D) While the notation after a statute can provide some information about its history, it is not comprehensive and doesn't typically include detailed information about legislative intent or discussions.

The correct approach involves using professional resources at a law library, which allows for efficient searching of session laws, tracing bill histories, and accessing legislative discussions and hearings. This method provides the most thorough and reliable way to research legislative intent and the progression of a statute over time.

documentation.title: Under FERPA, is a professor forbidden from publishing a gradebook that includes school-issued student IDs?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I have a college professor who publishes a gradebook where I can find my grade simply by looking up my student ID \#, which I do not believe I can change. Until recently, I was able to look at the attendance sheet and correlate student IDs with legal names. However \- upon my polite asking \- the professor removed the student IDs from the attendance roll. While I appreciate her reaction to my note, I do not believe this is enough.

Am I right?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes and no, mostly yes. The university stands between the federal government and the professor: the federal government requires things of institutions, which in turn establishes policies that implement those government rules. The statutory link is a restriction on federal funding to violator institutions, via [20 USC 1232g](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/20/1232g). This is fleshed out in [34 CFR 99](http://www.ecfr.gov/cgi-bin/text-idx?tpl=/ecfrbrowse/Title34/34cfr99_main_02.tpl), and starting with §99\.30, there is extensive regulation of disclosing information. A university will (or should) then articulate privacy policies that say what employees may and may not do. Typically, universities impose ludicrous restrictions in order to cover their back pockets. (Following the letter of the rules, my university requires professors who communicate on academic matters with students, using email, that they do so on campus, using campus computers, sending to and from official university email addresses, and the email is to be encrypted – AFAIK this requirement is never obeyed).

It is not inconceivable that some university has a privacy policy that fails to expressly forbid posting information about the student. (It is even possible that there has been a legal development whereby such behavior is now allowed). It can be difficult to determine what those internal policies are, i.e. they may be buried in a big pile with other information, it may be called something else like "institutional data policy"; the online version of the policy is often not findable due to dead links. Typically, the Registrar can provide the desired information.

42.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A university professor posts a gradebook online where students can find their grades by looking up their student ID numbers. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal implications of this practice?

A) This practice is always permissible under federal law as long as student names are not directly linked to the ID numbers.

B) The legality of this practice depends primarily on the specific policies implemented by the university to comply with federal regulations.

C) Posting grades linked to student ID numbers is explicitly forbidden by the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA).

D) Professors have full discretion in how they share grade information, regardless of university policies.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. The legality of posting grades linked to student ID numbers depends primarily on the specific policies implemented by the university to comply with federal regulations. As explained in the documentation, federal law (20 USC 1232g) requires institutions to establish policies that protect student privacy. These policies are typically based on federal regulations (34 CFR 99) but may vary between institutions. 

Option A is incorrect because while removing names helps, it may not be sufficient if university policy prohibits linking grades to ID numbers. 

Option C is too absolute; FERPA doesn't explicitly forbid this practice, but rather requires institutions to implement their own privacy policies. 

Option D is incorrect because professors are bound by university policies, which are designed to comply with federal regulations.

The key point is that the university's specific policies, which should align with federal regulations, determine what practices are permissible for sharing grade information.

documentation.title: Can you take an employer to court for false promise?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: When I was interviewing for a contractor job, the hiring manager indicated many times that they would convert my position to full time job within one year. (I resigned from my full time job to take this contractor job due to his verbal promise).

During this time, I was offered full time jobs by other companies and I did not accept because of the promised conversion to full time. My manager even stated via Instant Messenger that my request was approved and I was going to be converted.

But, now he seems to be playing games and not being straight with me. One year latter, I am still not full time.

Do I have a case to go to court so that he cannot do the same thing to other potential future contractors?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: One case of a "false promise" suit from an employee to an employer can be seen in the ["Toy Yoda" suit](http://www.snopes.com/business/deals/hummer.asp), which was settled out of court in favour of the employee. 

As seen in [this news article](http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/2002/05/09/toy-yoda.htm):

> PANAMA CITY, Fla. (AP) — A former waitress has settled her lawsuit
>  against Hooters, the restaurant that gave her a toy Yoda doll instead
>  of the Toyota she thought she had won.
> 
> 
> Jodee Berry, 27, won a beer sales contest last May at the Panama City
>  Beach Hooters. She believed she had won a new Toyota and happily was
>  escorted to the restaurant's parking lot in a blindfold.
> 
> 
> But when the blindfold was removed, she found she had won a new toy
>  Yoda — the little green character from the Star Wars movies.
> 
> 
> David Noll, her attorney, said Wednesday that he could not disclose
>  the settlement's details, although he said Berry can now go to a local
>  car dealership and "pick out whatever type of Toyota she wants."
> 
> 
> After the stunt, Berry quit the restaurant and filed a lawsuit against
>  Gulf Coast Wings, the restaurant's corporate owner, alleging breach of
>  contract and fraudulent misrepresentation.

Therefore, at least in *some* cases, it is possible to sue an employer (and win) for false representation, especially if such claims are clearly made.

43.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Based on the "Toy Yoda" lawsuit case, which of the following statements best describes the legal implications for employers making false promises to employees or potential hires?

A) Employers can make any verbal promises without legal consequences, as long as they are not in writing.

B) Employees can only sue for breach of contract if the promise was made in a formal employment contract.

C) Verbal promises made by employers can potentially be legally binding and result in successful lawsuits if breached.

D) Employees have no legal recourse for false promises made during the hiring process or employment period.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The "Toy Yoda" case demonstrates that verbal promises made by employers can potentially be legally binding and result in successful lawsuits if breached. In this case, the waitress sued her employer for fraudulent misrepresentation and breach of contract based on a verbal promise, even though it was not part of a formal employment contract. The case was settled in favor of the employee, allowing her to receive the promised prize (a Toyota car). This shows that employees may have legal recourse when employers make false promises, even if they are not written in a formal contract. It's important to note that while not all verbal promises will necessarily result in successful lawsuits, this case illustrates that there can be legal consequences for employers who engage in deceptive practices or make false representations to their employees.

documentation.title: Is it legal to download Youtube captions, perform some analytical tasks on them and then display the results on your own website?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: There are many online services that analyze social media data and then display aggregate results. For instance the most frequent keywords in social media posts, etc. Is it legal to do something similar for Youtube captions? Is it legal to display parts of the captions on your own website?
I'm mainly interested in US jurisdiction, but advice for other countries is also appreciated.

From what I understand this use case would need to fall under ["fair use" doctrine](https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/6396261?hl=en), but it seems quite vague. The Youtube support FAQ states that:

> Borrowing small bits of material from an original work is more likely to be considered fair use than borrowing large portions. However, if it's the “heart” of the work, even a small amount may weigh against fair use in some situations.

So if I understand correctly displaying some captions metrics would be fair use if I don't include any quotes? What about a summary? It could be considered the “heart” of the work and therefore use would be illegal?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: None

44.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Under US copyright law, which of the following actions regarding YouTube captions would most likely be considered fair use?

A) Displaying full transcripts of YouTube video captions on your own website without permission
B) Analyzing YouTube captions to show the most frequent keywords used across multiple videos
C) Quoting large portions of YouTube captions, including the "heart" of the work, on your own site
D) Creating a summary of each YouTube video based entirely on its captions and publishing it online

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
A) is incorrect because displaying full transcripts without permission would likely infringe on copyright.
B) is the correct answer as it involves analyzing aggregate data without reproducing substantial portions of the original work, which is more likely to fall under fair use.
C) is incorrect because using large portions, especially the "heart" of the work, weighs against fair use.
D) is incorrect because creating summaries based entirely on captions could be seen as reproducing the essence of the original work, potentially infringing copyright.

Option B represents a transformative use of the data that doesn't reproduce significant portions of the original content, making it the most likely to be considered fair use under US copyright law.

documentation.title: i am charged with violating SORNA's registration. A county judge recently ruled SORNA unconstitutional. what to do? what should my ESQ do for me?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: charged with "failure to register", been on bail for over a year. have "call to the list" the 30th of this month for trial! my public defender shows no interest in defending me. two days i stumbled upon a local county judges' decision that SORNA and the registration process is punitive ruled it unconstitutional. I called my lawyer 3 times with no response. what should he be doing for me in response to this decision? i have NO faith in my lawyer and want to ensure i am getting a fair shake. this has been a very long road, and i appreciate any help and advice you could give me.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Generally, a local county judge’s decision is not binding on the judgement of another judge unless it is that of an appellate division.

The law of the case principle could be referred to as an argument if it would have been decided by another judge in the same case (some courtships work on a rotary basis with different judges sitting over a single case). This would mean that the court would give greater deference to that decision; however, applying the principle is a matter of administrative preference to save resources of the court. Whether or not the other judge would reconsider the matter would be within their discretion absent binding authority to the contrary as a “law of the case” is not binding.

In fact, even if it would have been the same judge with the exact same facts deciding the matter in a final judgement, there wouldn’t be much to do. One could argue that deciding differently is a violation of the Fourteenth Amendment which, if the judge fails to explain the different decision on the exact same facts may have a reasonable probability to get overturned provided the unconstitutionality finding was correct in the first place.

If the matter was, in fact, unconstitutional, appeals may overturn a contrary judgement if the issue is brought up in the lower court and enters the court record. It may have some weight still to cite the decision of the other judge as the argument may be given more weight than if merely delivered as the argument of counsel.

45.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A local county judge has ruled that SORNA (Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act) and the registration process is punitive and unconstitutional. In a separate case involving SORNA, how might this ruling impact the proceedings?

A) The ruling is automatically binding on all other judges in the county and must be followed.
B) The ruling has no impact and cannot be referenced in any way during the separate case.
C) The ruling can be cited as an argument, potentially giving more weight to the defense's position, but is not binding on the judge.
D) The ruling creates a "law of the case" that all judges in the county must follow unless overturned by an appellate court.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. As stated in the documentation, a local county judge's decision is generally not binding on the judgment of another judge unless it comes from an appellate division. However, the ruling can still be cited as an argument in a separate case. This citation may give more weight to the argument than if it were merely delivered as counsel's opinion. The judge in the separate case is not obligated to follow the ruling but may consider it. Options A and D are incorrect because local rulings are not automatically binding on other judges. Option B is incorrect because while the ruling is not binding, it can still be referenced and potentially influence the case.

documentation.title: Storm damage to tree
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: A storm broke a healthy branch which fell into neighbors backyard. If I have this now damaged tree removed, am I admitting liability for neighbors cleanup?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Not necessarily.

Many jurisdictions prohibit admission of evidence of subsequent remedial acts to show liability, although it could be admitted to show that it was possible to do something.

Also, the law of border trees is quite arcane and involved, and frequently subject to local ordinances, state laws, and common law rules all at once (and isn't terribly uniform from one place to another). But, usually, the bottom line for your liability to your neighbor will be whether you were negligent in maintaining the tree, which in the case of a healthy branch and an extraordinary storm, you usually would not be.

46.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A large, healthy oak tree straddles the property line between neighbors Smith and Jones. During a severe thunderstorm, a substantial branch breaks off and falls into Jones' yard, causing damage to Jones' garden shed. Smith promptly hires a tree service to remove the damaged tree entirely. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal implications of this situation?

A) By removing the tree, Smith has automatically admitted liability for the damage to Jones' property.

B) Smith's decision to remove the tree cannot be used as evidence of liability in court, but may be admissible to demonstrate that removal was possible.

C) Local ordinances always take precedence over state laws and common law rules in cases involving border trees.

D) If the branch was healthy before the storm, Smith is automatically liable for the damage because the tree was partially on his property.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. According to the information provided, many jurisdictions prohibit the admission of evidence of subsequent remedial acts (such as removing the tree) to show liability. However, such evidence might be admissible to show that it was possible to take action. This aligns with the statement in option B.

Option A is incorrect because removing the tree does not automatically admit liability, especially given the rules about subsequent remedial acts.

Option C is false because the law regarding border trees is described as involving a complex interplay of local ordinances, state laws, and common law rules, without a clear hierarchy always being present.

Option D is incorrect because liability typically depends on whether the property owner was negligent in maintaining the tree, not on automatic liability for trees partially on one's property. In the case of a healthy branch and an extraordinary storm, negligence would usually not be found.

This question tests understanding of multiple legal concepts, including evidence rules, property law, and the complexities of tree-related disputes between neighbors.

documentation.title: When is it illegal to carry opened alcohol in public?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I heard it's technically illegal to have an alcoholic beverage that is not in the same state it was sold in, in public. Does this mean

1. if a single can of beer is missing from a six pack it is illegal?
2. if a bottle of hard liquor has been opened and resealed, it is illegal?

Also, what is meant by "in public" in this context? For example if I'm walking down the street with a two six of vodka in my backpack that I had already drank from, would that be illegal? Does it matter if it's concealed?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [Section 73](https://www.bclaws.gov.bc.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/15019#section73) of the British Columbia's Liquor Control and Licensing Act is the relevant law...

> **Unlawful possession or consumption of liquor**
> 
> 
> s.73(1\) A person must not consume liquor, or possess liquor in an open
> container, in a place other than
> 
> 
> (a) a residence,
> 
> 
> (b) a private place,
> 
> 
> (c) a service area in respect of which a licence, authorization or
> permit allows consumption,
> 
> 
> (d) as provided under [section 11](https://www.bclaws.gov.bc.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/15019#section11),
> 
> 
> (e) as provided under subsections (2\) to (4\) of this section,
> 
> 
> (f) an assisted living residence, community care facility, hospital or
> other prescribed facility as provided in [section
> 9](https://www.bclaws.gov.bc.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/15019#section9),
> or
> 
> 
> (g) in a liquor store as allowed under the [Liquor Distribution Act.](https://www.bclaws.gov.bc.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/96268_01)
> 
> 
> (2\) Subject to subsection (3\) and the regulations, a public place, or
> part of it, may be designated, by a bylaw of the municipality or
> regional district that has jurisdiction over the public place, as a
> place where liquor may be consumed.
> 
> 
> (3\) A bylaw under subsection (2\) must contain the hours during which
> liquor may be consumed.
> 
> 
> (4\) Without limiting subsection (2\), regulations under that subsection
> may provide that a bylaw referred to in that subsection may not
> designate
> 
> 
> (a) a specified public place, or
> 
> 
> (b) a specified public place for a specified period of time.

**If a single can of beer is missing from a six pack it is illegal?**

No, as long as none of the cans are open.

**If a bottle of hard liquor has been opened and resealed, it is illegal?**

Not in its resealed state, but the act of opening the bottle *may* be unlawful depending on the circumstances.

**What is meant by "in public" in this context**

Everywhere not accounted for in s.73, above.

**If I'm walking down the street with a two six of vodka in my backpack that I had already drank from, would that be illegal?**

Not if the lid is on the vodka bottle as it's not an "open container". When and where you drank it is another matter.

**Does it matter if it's concealed?**

No.

47.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Jack is walking down a public street in British Columbia with a backpack. Inside his backpack are:
1. A six-pack of beer with one can missing
2. An unopened bottle of wine
3. A half-empty bottle of vodka with the cap screwed on
4. An open can of beer

Which of the following statements is correct regarding the legality of Jack's situation?

A) Jack is breaking the law because he has an open can of beer in his possession in public.

B) Jack is not breaking any laws because all containers are inside his backpack and therefore concealed from public view.

C) Jack is breaking the law because he has a half-empty bottle of vodka, which is considered an "open container" regardless of whether it's sealed or not.

D) Jack is breaking the law because he has a six-pack of beer with one can missing, which is illegal to transport in public.

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: According to Section 73 of British Columbia's Liquor Control and Licensing Act, it is unlawful to possess liquor in an open container in a public place. In this scenario:

1. The six-pack with a missing can is legal as long as the remaining cans are unopened.
2. The unopened bottle of wine is legal to possess in public.
3. The half-empty bottle of vodka is legal as long as the cap is screwed on, as it's not considered an "open container" in this state.
4. The open can of beer is illegal to possess in public, even if it's in a backpack.

Concealment in a backpack does not change the legality of possessing an open container. Therefore, Jack is breaking the law only because of the open can of beer in his possession while in public.

documentation.title: Am I allowed to open source my Dr. Seuss txt files on GitHub?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I've been working on building a Dr. Seuss dataset which provides training data for my recurrent neural network. The goal is to use machine learning to get the computer to generate Seuss\-like works.

I was looking for an answer online and I saw that Seuss stuff isn't going to be in the public domain for quite awhile. But, does hosting it on github for educational/open source purposes put it under fair use?

To be clear, it's just a bunch of plaintext files with Seuss books/poems in them. They aren't all perfect, and of course there are no illustrations, and the 'form' is rarely perfectly represented, but they definitely all contain Seuss' intellectual property.

Is it possible to put it on Github? If so, under what possible licenses?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: **tl; dr:** Maybe, maybe not, but trouble seems likely. 

Your text files are clearly derived from Dr. Seuss' books, so you normally need the permission of the copyright holder of the books.

You mention "fair use" as a possible way around this. However, I don't think this will necessarily fly. The releveant regulation says:

> Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 106 and 106A, the fair use
>  of a copyrighted work, including such use by reproduction in copies or
>  phonorecords or by any other means specified by that section, for
>  purposes such as criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching
>  (including multiple copies for classroom use), scholarship, or
>  research, is not an infringement of copyright. In determining whether
>  the use made of a work in any particular case is a fair use the
>  factors to be considered shall include—
> 
> 
> (1\) the purpose and character of the use, including whether such use
>  is of a commercial nature or is for nonprofit educational purposes;
> 
> 
> (2\) the nature of the copyrighted work;
> 
> 
> (3\) the amount and substantiality of the portion used in relation to
>  the copyrighted work as a whole;
> 
> 
> (4\) the effect of the use upon the potential market for or value of the copyrighted work.
> 
> 
> \[...]

[*17 U.S. Code § 107 \- Limitations on exclusive rights: Fair use*](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/17/107)
So the main factors are:

* the kind of use intended
* the type of work
* the amount used
* the effect upon the market value for the work

The kind of use (research) is probably not a problem, as is the type of work (a published book).

However, the amount used (several/all the books) would speak against "fair use". Using some small excerpts from the books may be okay, but using *all of them* probably not.

One mitigating factor: The effect upon the market could be argued to be small, since you will not publish the illustrations, and the Dr Seuss books are arguable quite incomplete without them.

In summary: You may get lucky with the fair use defense, but I would not count on it. Using the book texts for research yourself could be okay, but publishing it most likely is not.

---

Additional reading:

The article [Text and Data Mining and Fair Use in the United States](http://www.arl.org/storage/documents/TDM-5JUNE2015.pdf) addresses your problem, and mentions some court cases. The fair use defense was upheld in some cases, but none of these published complete works, only excerpts.

48.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A researcher wants to create a dataset of Dr. Seuss books for machine learning purposes and share it on GitHub. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legality of this action under fair use doctrine?

A) Sharing the full text of Dr. Seuss books on GitHub is clearly protected under fair use because it's for educational and research purposes.

B) The researcher can safely share the dataset on GitHub as long as they don't include any illustrations from the original books.

C) Sharing the full text of multiple Dr. Seuss books is likely to be problematic under fair use, even for research purposes.

D) Fair use protections would definitely apply as long as the researcher doesn't make any profit from sharing the dataset.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: While fair use does provide some protections for educational and research purposes, sharing the full text of multiple copyrighted works is likely to be problematic. The amount of copyrighted material used is a key factor in fair use determination, and using entire books goes beyond what's typically considered acceptable. Even though it's for research and doesn't include illustrations, using complete texts of multiple books would likely exceed fair use limits. The non-profit nature of the project helps, but isn't sufficient on its own to guarantee fair use protection. Option C most accurately reflects the nuanced and potentially risky nature of this situation under copyright law.

documentation.title: Does a town have to have a justification for a zoning restriction?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: In one town near me there is a town that has zoning restrictions like, if an addition is over so\-and\-so many square feet it must have planning board approval.

This would seem to be capricious interference with property rights. If the house is on a multi\-acre lot and is not visible from any public roads, what business is it of the town, how big an addition is? It seems like interfering with building for the sake of being nosy and interfering. Since it costs money and time to seek such approvals, it is a real cost being imposed.

Is this kind of rule illegal, can I contest it in court, or do towns have the right to make arbitrary or pointless zoning restrictions at their whim?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Is this kind of rule illegal, can I contest it in court, or do towns
>  have the right to make arbitrary or pointless zoning restrictions at
>  their whim?

This kind of rule is completely legal. You could sue, but you would almost certainly lose. Generally speaking, towns have the right to make arbitrary or pointless zoning restrictions at their whim. This general rule is subject only to some very narrow exceptions:

1. They can't totally ban any particular kind of first amendment activity, although they can regulate time, place and manner (e.g. they can't completely ban topless establishments or churches or political gathering places, although they can say where these establishments can be located).
2. The regulations can't discriminate on their face on the basis of race or national origin, even though they can have a discriminatory effect that isn't the principal purpose of the regulations.
3. The town's regulations can't leave property with no economically viable use whatsoever without paying compensation to the owner.
4. The town must be able to articulate some basis for the zoning restriction, but pretty much any explanation whatsoever will do (which is to say that this kind of law is subject to the rational basis test).
5. There are meaningful limitations arising under federal law regarding the extent to which manufactured housing can be treated differently than conventionally build housing under the regulations. In practice, it is easy to adopt neutral regulations that make manufactured housing (i.e. trailer parks) uneconomic.
6. There are federal regulations that prohibit zoning laws from banning satellite dishes.
7. Zoning laws can't be changed retroactively. In other words, once something is built that conforms to current zoning laws, it is "grandfathered" notwithstanding future changes in the zoning laws, until the building at the site is destroyed or substantially renovated, except in the case of some very extreme and urgent health and safety threats.

Substantive state regulation of zoning laws is pretty much non\-existent, although state law may set forth a particular process that must be followed or require the regulations to fit a general template applicable in the state. Usually, however, states don't limit the authority of states to regulate land use at all. Where there is state regulation, this usually prevents regulation of something specific (e.g. political advertisements, a "right to farm" provision, prohibiting bans on xeriscaping, etc.).

49.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A small town in rural America has implemented a zoning ordinance that requires planning board approval for any home addition exceeding 500 square feet, regardless of property size or visibility from public roads. A homeowner with a 10-acre lot, whose house is not visible from any public road, wants to build a 600 square foot addition without seeking approval. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legality and potential challenge of this zoning ordinance?

A) The ordinance is likely illegal because it interferes with property rights on large, secluded lots and can be successfully challenged in court.

B) The ordinance is legal, but the homeowner can challenge it based on the rational basis test, as the town cannot articulate any reasonable explanation for the restriction.

C) The ordinance is legal and would likely withstand a court challenge, as towns generally have broad authority to implement zoning restrictions, even if they seem arbitrary.

D) The ordinance is illegal because it discriminates against large property owners and violates their First Amendment rights.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. As stated in the provided information, towns generally have the right to make zoning restrictions, even if they seem arbitrary or pointless. The ordinance in question does not violate any of the narrow exceptions mentioned (e.g., it doesn't discriminate based on race, completely ban a type of first amendment activity, or leave the property with no economically viable use). While the homeowner might find the restriction unnecessary or intrusive, courts typically defer to local governments on zoning matters unless they fall under specific exceptions. The town would likely be able to articulate some basis for the restriction, which would satisfy the rational basis test. Therefore, although the homeowner might disagree with the ordinance, it would likely be considered legal and withstand a court challenge.

documentation.title: Who needs to implement Cookie Consent for embedded content?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Given a page X that doesn't use cookies or only uses necessary cookies per GDRP and as such, doesn't need explicit Cookie Consent. The X is then modified to include a Youtube video using `<iframe>` element. (Youtube is used here as an example only. This question is about combining content from multiple different hosts in general.)

It seems that commonly *believed* solution is to require Cookie Consent on the host page. **Why?** The cookie is not set by the host document server. Its value cannot ever be seen by the server providing the host document for the `<iframe>` element even if the server administrator wanted to monitor their users.

To me, the obvious solution to the problem is that if *the embedded document* wants to save non\-necessary cookies, *it* should provide the cookie consent before storing such cookies.

**Are there any prior decisions in some jurisdiction that specify that *host document* should request the cookie consent instead?** And if so, how the host document is supposed to transfer information about this consent to embedded content hosting server? It doesn't sound reasonable to me that if your document is embbedded in a `<iframe>` element, you don't ever need the consent to set non\-necessary cookies.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The **data controller** is responsible for GDPR compliance. For embedded content, case law such as the Fashion ID case indicates a **joint controllership** where both the controller of the embedding page and the controller of the embedded content are controllers. However, one can only be controller for processing activities where one has influence on the means and purposes of processing. So the controller of the embedding page is a controller with respect to the act of embedding (with purposes like *showing a video*), but they wouldn't be a controller for subsequent processing by that embedded content (with purposes like *tracking people across the web*).

For determining who is a controller, it is not too helpful to look at which servers sent which HTTP headers. Instead, look at which processing activities occur, for what purposes that processing is carried out, and who had input to determining these purposes. Those (natural or legal) persons are data controllers and are therefore responsible for compliance.

What does this mean for the example of embedding a Youtube video, Tweet, or Like button?

The **controller of the embedding page** needs a legal basis for sharing visitor's personal data with the embed provider. Such a sharing is inevitable due to the embedding, regardless of whether cookies are involved. Typically, the legal basis used here would be consent: in place of the embed, a placeholder is shown that lets visitors opt in to loading the content. In some cases, a legitimate interest argument might also work.

Whether the embedded content ends up using cookies is outside of the embedding page's control. Thus, I would think the **controller of the embedded content** would be the sole controller with respect to these cookies. Of course, no consent is required for the use of cookies when this use is strictly necessary to provide the service requested by the user, e.g. to add a video to a logged\-in user's Youtube history.

The **joint controllers** can divide up compliance obligations among themselves. For example, the provider of the embed content could likely require embedders to collect necessary consents prior to embedding (Twitter has similar terms). However, this would be risky for the controller because controllers shall be able to demonstrate that valid consent was actually given.

So in **conclusion**, I largely agree with your analysis that the provider of the embedded content should consider cookie consent. With two caveats: the controllers might have an agreement that moves this responsibility to the embedder, and the embedding data controller might need consent to embed the content in the first place.

50.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A website owner embeds a YouTube video on their page using an <iframe> element. The website itself doesn't use any non-essential cookies. According to GDPR regulations and relevant case law, who is responsible for obtaining user consent for any non-essential cookies that may be set by the embedded YouTube content?

A) Only the website owner, as they are solely responsible for all content on their site
B) Only YouTube, as they are setting the cookies through their embedded content
C) Both the website owner and YouTube are jointly responsible, but for different aspects of data processing
D) Neither party is responsible, as embedded content is exempt from GDPR regulations

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the Fashion ID case and the concept of joint controllership under GDPR, both the website owner (who embeds the content) and YouTube (who provides the embedded content) have responsibilities, but for different aspects of data processing.

The website owner is considered a data controller for the act of embedding the video and sharing visitor data with YouTube. They would need a legal basis (typically consent) for this sharing of data, which occurs regardless of cookie usage.

YouTube, as the provider of the embedded content, would be the controller responsible for any non-essential cookies set by their content. They would need to ensure compliance with GDPR for these cookies.

While the two parties could potentially have an agreement that shifts some responsibilities (e.g., YouTube requiring embedders to collect consent), both parties remain controllers for their respective areas of influence over data processing.

Option A is incorrect because it oversimplifies the responsibility. Option B fails to acknowledge the website owner's role as a controller. Option D is incorrect as embedded content is not exempt from GDPR regulations.

documentation.title: Can casinos take player losses while avoiding payouts of winning by claiming "malfunction?"
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: It's very rare for players to hit the jackpot on a slot machine. Can a casino make sure they never have to pay that out by having the machines "malfunction" to display a larger\-than\-maximum amount in those rare cases, and then avoid having to pay out anything close to the maximum, while still retaining all the player losses? 

Example stories where the answer seems to be "yes" can be found with [Katrina Bookman](http://money.cnn.com/2017/06/15/news/jackpot-steak-dinner-katrina-bookman-lawsuit/index.html) or [Pauline McKee](http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/chi-iowa-casino-error-20150424-story.html). Both played the slots at casinos that kept the players' losses, until they were notified by slot machine hardware that they'd won \>$40M. Then the casinos pointed to signs “Malfunction voids all pays and plays,” and claimed that since the machines were malfunctioning, the casino didn't have to pay more than a couple dollars. The Iowa Supreme Court agreed with the casino in McKee's case and the New York State Gaming Commission agreed with the casino in Bookman's.

In [the words of Bookman's lawyer](http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/queens-casino-told-woman-43m-prize-slot-machine-malfunction-article-1.2854392), "the casino used the same broken machine to take money from players, and that everyone who used the machine should at least get their money back...Doesn’t that mean a place can claim a machine is broken every time somebody wins?" That is the question here.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: In the case of [McKee v. Isle of Capri Casinos](http://www.iowacourts.gov/About_the_Courts/Supreme_Court/Supreme_Court_Opinions/Recent_Opinions/20150424/14-0802.pdf), we can tell because that case has been legally decided. As the court says, there was a contract and "the patron was not entitled to the bonus under those rules", and plaintiff "failed to prove the necessary elements of either promissory or equitable estoppel". They did not "represent to her that a bonus would be available if she played the 
game", and did not "promise to pay the $41 million after the notice was displayed".

The (very complex) rules of the game are easily available on the machine, and there is a prominent disclaimer that "MALFUNCTION VOIDS ALL PAYS AND PLAYS". Under the rules, the winning configuration stated that she was entitled to $1\.85\. The problem was that it also announced "Bonus Award \- $41797550\.16". This was due to an inexplicable software error which in communicating with the central computer awarded a "legacy bonus", which is no part of the game in question. The maximum legacy bonus is $99999\.99; the manufacturer knows of the possibility of this kind of error and has implemented a fix that is thought to eliminate the problem.

The first point then is that the casino didn't just claim there was a malfunction, they proved that there was one. Second, the terms of the contract hold: she was entitled to $1\.85, and the extraneous message was not part of the contract. That is, she did not actually win the large payout, the malfunction was in saying that she received a bonus. If a patron could likewise prove that they had actually won but the machine malfunctioned to represent the situation as a loss, they would of course be entitled to the appropriate winnings. The problem simply resides in the difficulty of a patron proving that.

51.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A casino patron plays a slot machine and the screen displays a jackpot win of $50 million. The casino refuses to pay, citing a malfunction. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal situation?

A) The casino is always obligated to pay the amount displayed, regardless of any malfunction.

B) The casino can arbitrarily claim a malfunction to avoid paying any large jackpots.

C) The casino must prove there was an actual malfunction and that the displayed amount was not part of the game's rules.

D) The patron is entitled to their money back for all plays on that machine, even if it was functioning correctly before the jackpot display.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option A is incorrect because, as shown in the McKee v. Isle of Capri Casinos case, casinos are not obligated to pay amounts displayed due to malfunctions if they can prove the malfunction occurred.

Option B is incorrect because casinos cannot arbitrarily claim malfunctions. They must provide evidence of an actual malfunction, as demonstrated in the McKee case where the casino proved a software error occurred.

Option C is correct. The casino must prove there was an actual malfunction and that the displayed amount was not part of the game's rules. In the McKee case, the casino demonstrated that the "legacy bonus" displayed was not part of the game and exceeded the maximum possible bonus.

Option D is incorrect. While this argument was made by Katrina Bookman's lawyer, it is not supported by the court's decision in the McKee case. Players are not automatically entitled to refunds for previous plays if a machine later malfunctions.

documentation.title: Who can initiate the legal proceedings for hacking?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: If a server is owned and maintained by Organization A, but almost fully installed and configured by Person A, who is a employee of Organization A, then who initiates the legal proceedings regarding unauthorized access, if person B gets access without authorization?

Furthermore, if Person B gets into the server without consent of Person A, but with the consent of Organization A, what is the stance on that? Can Person A take Person B to court, or does the Organization overrule that due to ownership?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If the unauthorized access constitutes a crime, then typically it is the state (i.e., a public prosecutor) who initiates prosecution of the crime.

Anybody who claims damages [can start a civil legal proceeding](https://law.meta.stackexchange.com/q/235/10).

52.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In a complex scenario involving unauthorized server access, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding legal proceedings?

A) Only Organization A can initiate legal proceedings against Person B for unauthorized access, as they own the server.

B) Person A, as the primary configurator of the server, has exclusive rights to initiate legal proceedings against Person B, regardless of organizational consent.

C) If unauthorized access constitutes a crime, the state typically initiates prosecution, while civil proceedings for damages can be initiated by any party claiming harm.

D) Legal proceedings can only be initiated if both Organization A and Person A agree to pursue action against Person B.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C because it accurately reflects the nuanced legal reality presented in the documentation. Criminal prosecution for unauthorized access would typically be initiated by the state (public prosecutor) if the act constitutes a crime. However, civil legal proceedings for damages can be initiated by any party that claims to have suffered harm as a result of the unauthorized access. This could include Organization A (as the server owner), Person A (if they can demonstrate personal damages), or even other affected parties. The answer also correctly avoids making absolute statements about exclusive rights or required agreements between parties, which are not supported by the given information.

documentation.title: Could a third party revive a dead trademark if another company has unlawfully been using it?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Suppose Company "A" registered the trademark "John Doe" with the EUIPO. 

Company "A" has declared bankruptcy and been liquefied, but the trademark was retained by Company "A"'s founder. 

During this time, a local company began to illegally use the trademark "John Doe" in a singular jurisdiction, but was not sued by the trademark's owner, due to general indifference. 

The trademark "John Doe" has just expired, and its owner has no intent to use it in the future.

Could a third party then come along and re\-register the trademark "John Doe" (either in all EUIPO jurisdictions or all EUIPO jurisdictions except where the local company operates)? The question [Can I file the same trademark as one that is cancelled?](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/25898/can-i-file-the-same-trademark-as-one-that-is-cancelled) discusses how one cannot register a dead trademark if the owner intends to continue using it, etc. However, can the trademark also not be registered by a third party if another company has begun to unlawfully use it prior to its expiration?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The question appears to be directed at EU law, but I can answer only with respect to U.S. law.

In U.S. law, a trademark is something that arises from use and that registration only defines and recognizes. I don't know if this is true in the E.U.

In the U.S., a trademark lapses by operation of law when it ceases to be used and is infringed with impunity as some point, even if its registration is still in force. There would be no infringement if it was already abandoned as in the OP fact pattern.

In the U.S. a company that was actually using a trademark that had lapsed in the hands of another owner would have priority over someone who filed to use the trademark after the company that was actually using it, in the places and markets that the company actually using a trademark did so.

53.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Company X registered the trademark "BlueSky" with the EUIPO but went bankrupt. The founder retained the trademark. During this time, Company Y began using "BlueSky" in France without permission. The trademark has now expired, and the founder has no plans to use it. Company Z wants to register "BlueSky" with EUIPO. Which statement is most accurate regarding Company Z's ability to register the trademark?

A) Company Z can register "BlueSky" for all EUIPO jurisdictions without any issues.

B) Company Z cannot register "BlueSky" at all due to Company Y's use in France.

C) Company Z can register "BlueSky" for all EUIPO jurisdictions except France.

D) Company Z's ability to register "BlueSky" depends on whether Company Y has established rights through use in France.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. While the original trademark has expired and the founder has no intent to use it, Company Y's use in France, even if initially unauthorized, may have established some rights through actual use. In trademark law, especially in the U.S. (which may provide insight into other jurisdictions), rights can be established through use even without registration. Company Z's ability to register would likely depend on whether Company Y has established such rights in France through continuous use. This situation would require a careful examination of EU trademark law and the specific circumstances of Company Y's use in France. Options A and C are too definitive without considering Company Y's potential rights, while B is too restrictive given that the original trademark has expired and is not being used by its former owner.

documentation.title: Marking up a driver's license
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I'm not sure if this is the proper place for this question, but I want to know if coloring on a driver license invalidates it. I'm not talking about making real changes \- more like coloring in sleeves or filling in a neckline.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I'm a notary. If someone showed me a marked\-up license, I'd refuse to perform the notarization, and make a note of the persons name and phone number, to make sure I would never make another appointment with the person.

Is there a law that says I have to refuse? I don't think so. Is there is a law that says I can refuse if I have any doubts about the person's identity? Absolutely.

54.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A notary public is presented with a driver's license that has been colored on by the holder, with some decorative elements added to the photo such as colored-in sleeves and a filled-in neckline. The information on the license remains unaltered. What is the most appropriate action for the notary to take in this situation?

A) The notary must accept the license as valid identification and proceed with the notarization.
B) The notary should immediately report the altered license to local law enforcement.
C) The notary can refuse to perform the notarization based on doubts about the person's identity.
D) The notary is legally required to accept the license unless the identifying information has been changed.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the information provided, while there may not be a specific law requiring notaries to refuse altered licenses, they have the discretion to refuse service if they have any doubts about a person's identity. In this case, even though the alterations are decorative and don't change the identifying information, the fact that the license has been modified at all could reasonably cause the notary to doubt its authenticity or the holder's intentions. The notary's primary responsibility is to verify identity, and any alterations to an official document, even if seemingly innocuous, can compromise this process. Therefore, refusing to perform the notarization based on doubts about the person's identity is the most appropriate and safest course of action for the notary.

documentation.title: Distributing my own sexual photographs as a child?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Would it be illegal to distribute sexual photographs of myself as a child for free or in exchange for money given that I am an adult now?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The US child porn law is [Chapter 110 of Title 18](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/2256). It refers to a "minor", defined as anyone under 18\. Sexually explicit conduct is defined, which you can read about. Regarding distribution (not production), [18 USC 2252](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/2252) (A)(1\) identifies as an offender anyone who

> knowingly transports or ships using any means or facility of
>  interstate or foreign commerce or in or affecting interstate or
>  foreign commerce by any means including by computer or mails, any
>  visual depiction, if—
> 
> 
> (A) the producing of such visual depiction involves the use of a minor
>  engaging in sexually explicit conduct; and
> 
> 
> (B) such visual depiction is of such conduct;

"Affecting interstate commerce" is a term of legal art that means "doing, at all", which relates the law to the Commerce Clause and givers the federal government jurisdiction. There is a big interstate trade in child porn, and absolutely restricting distribution of child porn is part of what's necessary to regulate this form of interstate commerce (see [Wickard v. Filburn, 317 U.S. 111 (1942\)](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/317/111/case.html): "affecting interstate commerce" can be found even when a farmer grown wheat for home consumption).

There is no overriding of the law in case the minor is *now* an adult, and there is no overriding of the law if the producer, purchaser or distributor is the child in the porno.

The core prohibition is [18 USC 2251](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/2256), and distribution is covered in (d)(1\), which defines the person to be punished as one who

> knowingly makes, prints, or publishes, or causes to be made, printed,
>  or published, any notice or advertisement seeking or offering—
> 
> 
> (A) to receive, exchange, buy, produce, display, distribute, or
>  reproduce, any visual depiction, if the production of such visual
>  depiction involves the use of a minor engaging in sexually explicit
>  conduct and such visual depiction is of such conduct; or
> 
> 
> (B) participation in any act of sexually explicit conduct by or with
>  any minor for the purpose of producing a visual depiction of such
>  conduct;

55.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided legal information:

Question: An adult wants to sell photographs of themselves engaged in sexually explicit conduct when they were 16 years old. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the legality of this action under U.S. federal law?

A) It's legal because the person in the photos is now an adult and consenting to their distribution.
B) It's legal as long as the photos are only sold within the same state and don't cross state lines.
C) It's illegal under federal law, regardless of the current age of the person in the photos or who is distributing them.
D) It's legal if the person can prove they took the photos themselves when they were a minor.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. Under U.S. federal law, specifically 18 USC 2252 and 18 USC 2251, it is illegal to distribute any visual depiction of a minor (defined as anyone under 18) engaging in sexually explicit conduct, regardless of who is distributing the material or the current age of the person depicted. The law does not make exceptions for cases where the person in the images is now an adult or is the one distributing the images. The prohibition applies even if the distribution is within a single state, as it's considered to be "affecting interstate commerce." The fact that the person took the photos themselves when they were a minor does not create an exception to the law.

documentation.title: Ownership of sites and smart contracts
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: If I am an owner of a site, I can place restrictions on its usage even if the site software is licensed under an open source license such as GPL or AGPL, right? Which law allows me to place such restrictions? For example, I can disallow uploading porn to my site, right? I can forbid circumventing site payment system, such as by distributing site passwords to other users or by modifying (I think, it's called "hacking") the site scripts, right?

Do I have similar rights for an open source smart contract created and uploaded to public servers by me? Can I legally disallow certain usages of smart contract (such as retrieving data from it directly to download a paid file for free bypassing my user interface software)?

Note that I realize I have no rights to restrict usage of my source code of a smart contract, because it is open source. I ask about a particular instance of smart contract running (similarly to a particular site running on a particular domain not to its underlying open source software).

Smart contract is a computer program that runs on servers (you can assume they are third\-party servers) with the purpose to controls possible actions (such as money transfers) and disallow certain kinds of actions (like uncompensated money transfers).

I suspect it is something related to "terms of service". Can I apply terms of service to a running instance of a smart contact? I think, the main question is whether I am considered a service provider for the services provided by a smart contract: I spin it once and then the smart contract runs without my intervention (it is even not possible for me to stop my smart contract running, but I can for example change the amount of the monetary fee for its usage) on third\-party servers.

There is a thing (securing a public file) that I cannot restrict with logic of a smart contact. So I am seeking a legal ("if you violate, I can sue") way to disallow these actions.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Terms of service are contracts, where you grant a person a right in exchange for them doing something. If they have agreed but violate the terms, you may have legal recourse to sue them; or you can "undo" their action, e.g. you can delete porn that they uploaded. There are certain limitations on your recourse, for example you cannot fine a user $100 for posting a snarky comment, and this comes from contract law (no penalty clauses).

Regardless of the copyright status of any code you have running on your machine, you can set legal limits on how a program on your web page can be uses, for example you can stipulate "cannot be used for commercial purposes". The legal challenge would be for the provider to prove that they were actually harmed by the user's breach of contract: usually, the violator is just banned, which doesn't take a lawsuit. An indemnification clause is useful because it can require the user to take responsibility for legal damages that the user causes to you (for example, if they post defamatory content, they can be forced to cover your losses arising from the defamation lawsuit). You might have a hard time suing a person for making a snarky comment online, although the damage could be that it causes your snark\-free forum reputation and attendant customer base to evaporate.

If your program transfers money from a user account to a specified target account and the TOS requires the user to have money in the account but the software doesn't check the account, then "writing a rubber e\-check" would be a violation of the TOS and would cause damage, so you could sue. (For the sake of keeping this maximally related to the question you ask, I ignore the probability that online financial transactions are highly likely to be subject to other specific laws).

The comments suggests a complication, that there are two TOS's involved. There can be a front\-end server that has a TOS, and that server can "silently" call on a separate server with its other TOS. If your TOS and use of the third party server is consistent with the third party TOS, there is no problem. If you are using the third party server illegally, you bear the liability and your customers do not (unless you are clear about the nature of the third party TOS and that you disclaim responsibility for lawsuits arising from the customer's illegal use of the service). It is unlikely that the situation will arise, since the customer has no agreement with the third party that they breached. It is insufficient to just say "we have a TOS", you have to have actual agreement between the parties.

56.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A web developer creates a website using open-source software licensed under GPL. The developer wants to implement restrictions on how users can interact with the site. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the developer's ability to impose such restrictions?

A) The developer cannot place any restrictions on site usage because the underlying software is open-source.

B) The developer can only restrict usage that directly violates the GPL license terms.

C) The developer can implement Terms of Service to restrict site usage, but cannot enforce monetary penalties for violations.

D) The developer has complete freedom to restrict any type of usage without limitations.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. While the underlying software may be open-source, the website owner can still implement Terms of Service (ToS) to restrict how users interact with their specific instance of the site. These ToS act as a contract between the site owner and users. The owner can restrict activities like uploading certain content or bypassing payment systems. However, there are limitations on enforcement. For example, the owner cannot impose excessive monetary penalties for violations, as this would likely be considered an unenforceable penalty clause under contract law. The owner's primary recourse would typically be to ban users or remove violating content. They could potentially sue for damages if they can prove actual harm from the violation, but this is often difficult in practice. The other options are incorrect because A) ignores the ability to restrict usage of a specific site instance, B) unnecessarily limits restrictions to GPL terms only, and D) overstates the freedom to restrict without any limitations.

documentation.title: Why are judges allowed to read news and media opinions?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I find it interesting that apparently judges are allowed to read news and opinions about the litigation in front of them, whereas juries would not be.

Why is there such a distinction, and are there any limitations to ensure fair rulings?

For example, this is regarding [Citing previous Malibu Media’s sheer abuse of court process, New York judge denies early discovery](http://fightcopyrighttrolls.com/2015/07/06/citing-previous-malibu-medias-sheer-abuse-of-court-process-new-york-judge-denies-early-discovery/) (via [DSLR: King v. TWC](http://www.dslreports.com/shownews/Time-Warner-Cable-Sued-For-Robocalling-Wrong-Woman153-Times-134405)), where the judge apparently cites some industry study about copyright trolls, and explicitly names the plaintiff as such, denying its motions and dropping the lawsuit.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Your question slightly misrepresents what the article says: Yes, the judge denied the motion which led to the collapse of the case, he did not make a ruling on the substance of the case.

The distinction is significant to my mind as the judge was using non\-evidentiary knowledge (i.e. what he read in the paper) to make a decision on **process**; in this case a process that would have put a lot of people to a lot of inconvenience. It would not be proper for the judge to have used such knowledge to inform a **judgement**.

It is also not clear from the article if the academic paper in question was actually introduced by the defendant as evidence. If that was the case then it is only right and proper for the judge to consider it.

As to why a judge is allowed to read the news and a jury is not, I can offer several ideas:

1. A judge must document their reasoning process in a judgement which is subject to review \- if they were to make a decision based on matters not supported by the evidence then an appeals court could correct it. Alternatively, juries are specifically prohibited from revealing their reasoning process to *anyone*.
2. Judges do their jobs for years, perhaps a whole career \- to prohibit them from consuming media is a) unworkable and b) a serious impediment on their lifestyle. Juries are empaneled for weeks or months \- such sacrifices are more reasonable.
3. Judges are (supposedly) trained and impartial professionals who are more readily able to make the distinction between evidence and news.
4. Newsworthy cases are relatively rare

57.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: According to the information provided, why are judges generally allowed to read news and opinions about ongoing litigation, while jurors are not?

A) Judges have more legal training and are better equipped to distinguish between evidence and news
B) Prohibiting judges from consuming media would be impractical due to the length of their careers
C) Judges must document their reasoning in judgments that are subject to review
D) All of the above

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The passage provides multiple reasons for the distinction between judges and jurors regarding access to news and opinions about ongoing cases. These reasons include:

1. Judges are trained professionals who are considered more capable of distinguishing between evidence and news (option A).
2. Prohibiting judges from consuming media for their entire careers would be unworkable and a significant lifestyle impediment, unlike the shorter-term restrictions placed on jurors (option B).
3. Judges are required to document their reasoning in judgments that can be reviewed by higher courts, allowing for corrections if decisions are based on matters not supported by evidence (option C).

Since all of these reasons are valid according to the passage, the correct answer is D) All of the above, which encompasses all the key points mentioned.

documentation.title: Is it possible to get extradicted to a country you never have been to?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I'm trying to wrap my head around the [MegaUpload / Kim Dotcom case](https://law.stackexchange.com/a/5149/8901) for quite a while now. On twitter he [claims](https://twitter.com/KimDotcom/status/582068295366410240):

> I never lived there
> 
> 
> I never traveled there
> 
> 
> I had no company there
> 
> 
> But all I worked for now belongs to the U.S.

Now I came across a news item on the German portal [Spiegel Online](http://www.spiegel.de/netzwelt/web/anhoerung-in-neuseeland-dotcom-wehrt-sich-gegen-auslieferung-a-1109396.html) that says Kim Dotcom is about to be handed over to the U.S. authorities by a N.Z. court.

Now I am wondering: He never had any company in the U.S., also he claims to never having been or lived there. Is it even possible to be prosecuted unter U.S. law? It sounds a bit weird to me. Also, is it possible to get extradicted to a country you never have been to?

Personally, to me the scary part is: Do I need to make sure I do not break any laws in *any* country of the world in the future, not only in the country I live? Or is this a difficult question to answer because the accusations against him are related to internet business?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes.
----

Kim Dotcom is alleged to have committed a crime against US law. The US requested his arrest by NZ authorities with whom they have an extradition treaty. He has now had his extradition hearing and the NZ court is satisfied that, under NZ law, he should be extradited to face those charges.

You do not have to be a citizen of a country to offend its laws. You do not have to be located within its borders.

For example, if you rob a US bank over the internet you are liable to prosecution in the US no matter where you are in the world. Similarly, if you plot a terrorist attack.

58.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Under what circumstances can a person be extradited to face charges in a country they have never visited?

A) Only if they are a citizen of that country
B) Never, as physical presence is required to commit a crime
C) If they have committed a crime that affects that country, regardless of their location
D) Only if they have business operations in that country

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. As demonstrated in the Kim Dotcom case, a person can be extradited to face charges in a country they have never visited if they are alleged to have committed a crime that affects that country, regardless of their physical location. This is particularly relevant in the digital age, where crimes can be committed across borders via the internet.

Answer A is incorrect because citizenship is not a requirement for prosecution or extradition. 

Answer B is false because physical presence is not always necessary to commit a crime, especially in cases involving cybercrime or international financial crimes.

Answer D is too narrow, as having business operations in a country is not a prerequisite for committing a crime against its laws or being subject to extradition.

This question tests understanding of international law, extradition treaties, and the global nature of certain crimes in the modern world.

documentation.title: Can California counties make their own traffic laws?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: The state lays out traffic laws pretty clearly, but our county has some specific traffic needs (winter/snow issues). We're looking at having flasing green on recovery vehicles on route to their jobs. 

Can a county make a regulation like that?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [State law](https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displayText.xhtml?lawCode=VEH&division=12.&title=&part=&chapter=2.&article=7.) regulates the use of flashing and colored lights. Veh. Code 25250 says that "Flashing lights are prohibited on vehicles except as otherwise permitted", so if the state does not permit it, the county can't say anything about it. The list of permissions includes "making a turn", as a warning with parked on the side of the road, to warn of funeral procession, and nothing like what you describe.

The state does cover tow trucks in 25253:

> (a) Tow trucks used to tow disabled vehicles shall be equipped with
>  flashing amber warning lamps. This subdivision does not apply to a
>  tractor\-trailer combination.
> 
> 
> (b) Tow trucks may display flashing amber warning lamps while
>  providing service to a disabled vehicle. A flashing amber warning lamp
>  upon a tow truck may be displayed to the rear when the tow truck is
>  towing a vehicle and moving at a speed slower than the normal flow of
>  traffic.
> 
> 
> (c) A tow truck shall not display flashing amber warning lamps on a
>  freeway except when an unusual traffic hazard or extreme hazard
>  exists.

So first, the lights would have to be amber. Second, they can't be always flashing (it is allowed only when "actually towing"). Because state law forbids flashing lights except as specified, the described use is not specified, so it is forbidden.

59.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A county in California is considering implementing a regulation allowing recovery vehicles to use flashing green lights while en route to their jobs. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this proposed regulation?

A) The county can implement this regulation as long as it only applies to county-owned recovery vehicles.

B) The county can implement this regulation if it obtains permission from the state legislature.

C) The county cannot implement this regulation because it conflicts with state law, which prohibits flashing lights except as specifically permitted.

D) The county can implement this regulation, but only if the flashing green lights are used in conjunction with amber warning lamps.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to California Vehicle Code 25250, flashing lights are prohibited on vehicles except as otherwise permitted by state law. The state law specifically regulates the use of flashing and colored lights on vehicles, including tow trucks (recovery vehicles). The law allows flashing amber warning lamps for tow trucks under certain conditions, but does not permit flashing green lights for the purpose described. Since state law takes precedence and does not allow for this specific use of flashing green lights, the county cannot implement a regulation that conflicts with state law.
